unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Linear Regression $T$-Interval
question_text: A linear regression $T$-interval attempts to estimate

choices.text: The true population difference between two sample means of bivariate data.
The true population difference between two sample proportions when plotted on a scatterplot.
The true population mean of the response variable in linear regression.
The true population slope of the least squares regression line when two continuous variables are plotted.
The sample slope of the least squares regression line when two continuous variables are plotted.

solution:
In a linear regression confidence interval, bivariate sample data is used to estimate what the true population slope is.

Usually, computer output will already give the slope for the sample data. The interval is constructed by taking the sample slope, plus or minus the critical $t^*$ value, times the standard deviation of the slope.

The $t^*$ value can be found in table B looking it up with $n-2$ degrees of freedom based of off desired confidence, and the standard deviation of the slope will be given to you.

This interval will give a range of intervals that will likely catch the true population slope.

The formula for the interval is given below:

$$b \pm t^* SE_b$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. One never needs to perform inferential procedures for sample data; the sample means can always be found using single variable statistics.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. While this selection sounds good, two sample proportions would not reasonably be plotted on a scatterplot. Scatterplots are used to plot quantitative data, while proportions deal with categorical data.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. A linear regression $T$-interval measures the slope, NOT the response variable ($y$).

Choice 'E' is incorrect. Any inferential procedure hopes to give a snapshot of population data, not sample data. While this selection is correct when it says slope, it is the population slope, not sample slope that we are interested in.
